article_title: Revenue Up, Profits Down: Matthew Ball's 2026 Gaming Report Reveals an Industry at Odds With Itself
summary: Manual source verification revealed a factual misattribution and reliance on a non-reputable outlet. Changes required before publication.

findings.message: 84% domestic spending claim misattributed to gamigion.com
findings.details: The article states 'Chinese players direct 84% of their spending to domestic titles' citing gamigion.com, but that source's 84% figure refers to live services as a share of global industry revenue — not Chinese domestic spending. These are entirely different claims. The Chinese domestic spending figure requires a corrected source or must be dropped.

findings.message: gamigion.com is not a reputable trade publication
findings.details: gamigion.com presents as a personal blog/commentary platform ('My 5 Takeaways') rather than an established industry outlet. It should not be used as a citable source. All claims drawn from it must be re-sourced from a recognised outlet (e.g. gamedeveloper.com, pocketgamer.biz, polygon.com, ign.com).

findings.message: Growth rate figure: article says 5.3%, pocketgamer.biz says 5%
findings.details: The article states '$195.6 billion in 2025, a 5.3% year-over-year increase' but the pocketgamer.biz source reads '5% YoY'. Verify against the primary Matthew Ball report and use the correct figure.

findings.message: Console software $41.6B and pre-seed <$100M figures not found in cited sources
findings.details: The $41.6B console software revenue and the 'pre-seed investment dropped below $100 million in Q4 2025' figures could not be located in their respectively cited sources (pocketgamer.biz and wccftech.com). These should be verified against the primary Ball report or attributed to an accessible source.

findings.message: Nintendo Switch 2 pace comparisons are derived calculations, not verbatim from gamedeveloper.com
findings.details: The '77% faster than original Switch' and '5% ahead of PS4 launch trajectory' figures are calculated from raw unit data in the gamedeveloper.com article, not stated figures. The article should attribute these as derived comparisons or use a source where they appear explicitly.

content_preview.title: Revenue Up, Profits Down: Matthew Ball's 2026 Gaming Report Reveals an Industry at Odds With Itself
content_preview.summary: Matthew Ball's State of Video Gaming 2026 finds a $195.6B industry where record revenues mask falling margins, a funding drought, and China's growing dominance over global growth.
content_preview.body_excerpt:
## Overview

The global video game industry posted record revenues in 2025, yet an annual industry report from media analyst Matthew Ball argues that the headline number obscures a more complicated picture: margins have collapsed to below 2019 levels, private investment has cratered, and Chinese publishers are quietly capturing an outsized share of the industry's growth. Ball's [State of Video Gaming in 2026](https://www.pocketgamer.biz/matthew-balls-state-of-video-gaming-in-2026-china-is-eating...

editor_notes.content_quality: Well-structured Analysis piece at 1,132 words (within the 800-2000 word range). Engaging thesis, logical section flow, and clear synthesis of Ball's report findings. Writing quality is high.
editor_notes.source_verification: Sources verified against content. pocketgamer.biz and gamedeveloper.com are established, reputable gaming trade outlets. variety.com is a credible entertainment trade publication. wccftech.com is widely read but has mixed editorial rigour — an internal numerical discrepancy ($195.6B headline vs $196.5B in article body) was noted. gamigion.com is a personal commentary blog and not suitable as a citable source.
editor_notes.factual_accuracy: Critical error found: the claim 'Chinese players direct 84% of their spending to domestic titles' is a misattribution. The gamigion.com source uses the 84% figure to describe live services as a share of global industry revenue, not Chinese domestic spending. Several secondary figures (5.3% vs 5%, $41.6B console revenue, pre-seed <$100M in Q4) also require verification against the primary report.
editor_notes.tone_assessment: Neutral and analytical throughout. No sensationalism, no AI self-reference, no editorialising beyond standard analysis framing. Tone is appropriate for the Analysis category.
editor_notes.originality: No duplicate or closely overlapping articles found in recent published content. The most related recent article was the Ubisoft strike piece (Feb 14), which covers a different angle. This report-driven industry analysis is genuinely new content.
concerns: Factual misattribution of the 84% Chinese domestic spending figure — this is the primary blocker
gamigion.com is not a reputable source and should be replaced
Minor: 5.3% growth rate should be verified (pocketgamer.biz states 5%)
Minor: $41.6B console software and pre-seed <$100M figures unverifiable in cited sources
recommendations: Correct or remove the '84% of their spending to domestic titles' claim; source it properly from the Ball report or an established outlet, or replace it with the accurate global live services figure (84% of industry revenue) with correct attribution
Replace gamigion.com with a recognised outlet for the social media attention data and any other claims drawn from that source
Verify the 5.3% vs 5% YoY growth figure against the primary Ball report
Verify or rephrase the $41.6B and pre-seed <$100M figures with accessible citations
Consider phrasing the Nintendo pace comparisons as derived estimates (e.g. 'roughly 77% faster') rather than stated facts if they are not explicitly cited
editor_notes.overall_assessment: Strong article held back by a factual misattribution and reliance on a non-reputable source. The core analysis is compelling and the writing quality is high. These issues are correctable in a revision.

recommendations: Consider adding trusted domains (pocketgamer.biz, variety.com, gamedeveloper.com) to config/source_allowlist.txt
